title: Can the owner quitclaim a property during initial filing for Bankruptcy Chapter 13?
question: The bank supposed to foreclose my cousin's house next week so she filed for Chapter 13 BK today to prevent it from happening. However, now she is changing her mind and doesn't want to go through with her BK filing. She asked if she can quitclaim the house to my name and have me take care of the foreclosure problem instead of her, since I am is preparing to file for Chapter 7 BK. 1)Can she quitclaim the house to me after her initial BK Chapter 13 filing but still have many documents missing to fully execute the filing? 2) What will happen to the house or what will the bank do since my cousin's name is on the loan but my name is on the title. 3) Can she really be saved by quitclaim the house to me and let me handle the problems?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate documents,Real estate buy and sell agreements,Real estate quitclaim deed,Property title,Real estate finances,Foreclosure,Avoiding property foreclosure,Short sales,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Deed of trust
answers: Quitclaiming to someone else who is going to file for bankruptcy is a way to delay the foreclosure. By transferring the title to you by quitclaim, the automatic stay that takes effect when you file for Chapter 7 bankruptcy will prevent the bank from selling the house without first seeking permission from the bankruptcy court. It is an abuse of the automatic stay. When you file for bankruptcy your case will be affected by the scheme to have the property quitclaimed to you for no real reason but to take advantage of the automatic stay. The court might deem your involvement to be in bad faith and you could be denied a discharge or who knows what else depending on the circumstances. Your cousin should either dismiss her case if it was only filed to stop the sale or convert to Chapter 7 if she needs to have debts discharged such as credit card bills or a second loan on the house she is about to lose. You should stay away from your cousins problems. She needs to see a lawyer to find the best alternative for her situation and not get you involved in her problems, particularly since there will be little or no benefit to anyone.

Your cousin may be required to get the court's permission to sell the house. You will be required to find a company to finance the purchase. If the sales price is not enough to pay off all mortgages, then the creditors will not agree and neither will the court.

A quitclaim deed will cause more problems than it solves and may lead to losing the house anyway.

The answer is a resounding NO. Executing a quitclaim deed can only create more problems as it will be deemed a fraudulent transfer. A quitclaim does NOT transfer the obligation under the deed of trust and note.

I HIGHLY recommend your cousin and you call my office to set up a free consultation with me to discuss your options.

If she has equity in the home, she could run afoul of the fraudulent transfer laws. Right now, she is protected by her chapter 13 automatic stay, but if she wants to surrender the home and either dismiss her 13 or convert it to a chapter 7, then the lender will proceed with foreclosure if it is not being paid.

If she has no equity and deeds the property to you, she is violating her mortgage terms, but the lender might just want to keep getting paid and may work with you. The better approach here is that she list it for sale and you offer to purchase it through a short sale, where the lender agrees to take less than is due as payment in full, and the real estate professional can confirm that your offer price is the best the market can bear.

It is not clear what you mean when you ask "can she really be saved..."

You both need assistance of counsel, as this is not something that can be accomplished without someone who knows the full legal effect of what you are proposing.
